qas.question: What is quicker, a bipolar n-p-n transistor or a p-n-p transistor?
What semiconductor has the highest electron mobility?
What is the common application of GaAs?
What are common applications of HEMT?
What is the most common kind of semiconductor?

plausible_answers.text: the highest electron mobility of the three semiconductors

qas.question: What causes HEMTs to have high speed and low noise?
Which material has the highest electron mobility?
Where are HEMTs most commonly used?

context: Because the electron mobility is higher than the hole mobility for all semiconductor materials, <a0_0>a given bipolar n–p–n transistor<a0_0/> tends to be swifter than an equivalent p–n–p transistor. <a1_0><b5_0>GaAs<b5_0/><a1_0/> has <b6_0>the highest electron mobility of the three semiconductors<b6_0/>. It is for this reason that GaAs is used in <a2_0><b8_0>high-frequency applications<b8_0/><a2_0/>. A relatively recent FET development, the <a3_0>high-electron-mobility transistor<a3_0/> (HEMT), has a heterostructure (junction between different semiconductor materials) of aluminium gallium arsenide (AlGaAs)-gallium arsenide (GaAs) which has twice the electron mobility of a GaAs-metal barrier junction. Because of their high speed and low noise, HEMTs are used in <a4_0>satellite receivers<a4_0/> working at frequencies around 12 GHz. HEMTs based on gallium nitride and <b7_0>aluminium gallium nitride<b7_0/> (AlGaN/GaN HEMTs) provide a still higher electron mobility and are being developed for various applications.
